results.title: Les Camisards = the French Calvinists
results.brief_description:
Les Camisards’ brings events to the screen from the period in which King Louis XIV revoked the Act on Religious Tolerance (1685) and ordered French Protestants to convert to Catholicism or face persecutions. Rather than being a sweeping epic, this film examines the fight of a small group of Protestants for survival in the mountainous Cevennes region. Some of the story is told using excerpts from the diary kept by an actual participant in the conflict. The movie is notable for its period authenticity and historical accuracy.

Credits: Director, Rene Allio ; writers, Jean Jourdheuil, Rene Allio ; photography, Denys Clairval ; music, Philippe Arthuys.
Cast: Francois Marthouret, Dominique Labourier, Rufus, Isabelle Sadoyan, Jacques Debary, Genevieve Mnich, Maurice Benichou, Suzy Rambaud, Jean Benguigui, Christine Laurent.

results.title: Les Beaux souvenirs
results.creator_credit: Jean Dansereau, ONF | NFB and Francis Maikiewiez
results.brief_description: A middle-class wife leaves her husband with two young daughters. Through a series of occasional flash-backs, a contrast is made between the seemingly happy family relationship when the girls were young and the shattered threesome in later years. Starring Monique Spaziani, Julie Vincent and Paul Herbert.

results.title: Les Aventures de Salavin = the Adventures of Salavin
results.brief_description:
The Salavin cycle describes the frustrations and perplexities of a ‘little man’ of the 20th century trying to work out his own salvation with no religious faith to sustain him.

Credits: Producer, Edgar Roulleau ; director, Pierre Granier-Deferre ; writers, Pierre Granier-Deferre, R. M. Arland ; photography, Rene Bucaille ; music, Claude Bolling.
Cast: Maurice Biraud, Christiane Minazzoli, Mona Dol, Genevieve Fontanel, Julien Carette.

results.title: Les Annees Folles = the Crazy Years
results.brief_description:
The Roaring Twenties (The Crazy Years) were a time of carefree living, unbridled creativity and political upheaval. This documentary is a made up of a compilation of newsreels from the archives of Pathe and Gaumont.

Credits: Directors, Henri Torrent, Mirea Alexandresco ; music, Georges Van Parys, Georges Tzipine ; narration, Serge Reggiani.

results.title: Les Animaux = the Animals
results.brief_description:
Les animaux’ unveils nine aspects of animal life: origins of life, underwater world, species of four regions of the world, animal language, nocturnal animals, struggle for life, play, love.

Credits: Director, Frederic Rossif ; writer, Frederic Rossif ; photography, Georges Barsky.
Cast: Maurice Escande [narration].

results.title: Les Anciens de Saint-Loup = the Old Boys of Saint-Loup
results.brief_description:
Thre former students of the St Loup college reunite to investigate the mysterious murder of the director’s niece.

Credits: Producer, Jacques Roitfeld ; director, Georges Lampin ; writers, Pierre Very, Georges Lampin ; photography, Louis Page ; music, Georges van Parys.
Cast: Bernard Blier, Odile Versois, Francois Perier, Monique Melinand, Serge Reggiani.

results.title: Leopold: the see-through crumbpicker (K)
results.creator_credit: William Bernal, Firebird Films, Kratky Film and Gene Deitch
results.brief_description: Leopold is an invisible creature who creates havoc as he devours every crumb in sight. How his good friend Minerva renders him visible - and where he ends up when she does - is the amusing outcome of this action-filled tale. Based on the book written and illustrated by James Flora.

results.title: Leonardo. The Divine Michelangelo
results.creator_credit: Leslie Megahey, British Broadcasting Corporation and Discovery Channel
results.brief_description: Two fascinating documentary television series about the most influential artists of the Italian Renaissance. The first disc contains three parts to the television series about Leonard da Vinci and his work/creations. Written and presented by Alan Yentob. Presented as docu-drama with actors playing the roles of Leonardo and his contemporaries in a costume-drama style setting, with mock interviews and commentaries to make what would otherwise be straightforward information be imparted in a most enlightening and educative/entertaining way. The second disc contains two parts to the television series about Michelangelo. Narrated by Susannah York. “Program One” is about his triumph of the statue of David and “Program Two” is about the painting of the Sistine Chapel and his architectural designs.
